oai_dc:dc.dc:title: These pictures show how WAVES replace men for duty on sea and in the air
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper article that gives the picture and description of six different jobs performed by Navy WAVES (Women Accepted for Volunteer Emergency Service). The women in this article held positions at the Memphis Naval Air Centers.

Because of the volume of soldiers needed on the front lines during World War II, the United States government allowed women to fill non-combatant positions in the military in order to release as many men as possible for fighting. Every branch of the military incorporated women into their ranks in some fashion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War 1939-1945; Women and the military; United States-- Armed Forces--Women's Reserves; United States-- Armed Forces-- Women; World War 1939-1945-- Participation, Female-- Tennessee; World War 1939-1945-- War Work-- Tennessee
Military Facilities; Women; Military life
